talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.label: 1, 2 and 3.
item.para: Section 114 of the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution provides, inter alia, that a State shall not without the consent of the Parliament of the Commonwealth impose any tax on property of any kind belonging to the Commonwealth. It was held by the High Court that to levy a municipal rate upon Commonwealth property is to impose a tax within the meaning of section 114, Municipal Council of Sydney v. Commonwealth (1904) 1 C.L.R. 208, 10 A.L.R. (C.N.) 29. However, in certain circumstances the Commonwealth may agree to an ex gratia payment to a rating authority in lieu of rates. For example, in the case of a Commonwealth-owned dwelling where the occupant is paying an economic rental the ex gratia payment may be equivalent of the amount of rates payable if the dwelling were privately owned. The Commonwealth does not pay rates in respect of Commonwealthowned buildings used for office purposes.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for National Development, upon notice -

item.para: How many houses have been built under the (a) War service homes scheme and (b) the Commonwealth/State Housing Agreement since the inception of each scheme?
What total sums have been provided for the purpose of each scheme since its inception and what funds were provided during the year 1961/62?
What total repayments have been made to the Treasury in respect of each scheme since its inception, and what sums were repaid during the year 1961/62?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for National Development has supplied the following information: -

item.para: Houses built under each scheme from inception to 30th June, 1962 were- (a) 84,272, (b) 159,893.
The funds provided for the purposes of each scheme have been -
Payments made to the Treasury in respect of each scheme have been -

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Labour and National Service, upon notice -

item.para: How many (a) males and (b) females are registered for employment at the Commonwealth Employment Office at Newtown, Sydney?
What was the number registered in each category at this office during each month of the past year?
Of those registered at this date, how many are in the age groups of 16 to 20 years, 21 to 25 years, 26 to 30 years, 31 to 40 years, 41 to 50 years, and over 50 years?

talk.start.para: - The anwers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.label: 1 and 2.
item.para: Following are the numbers of (a) males and (b) females registered for employment with the district office of the Commonwealth Employment Service at Newtown at the end of each of the twelve months up to and including

list.para: July, 1962, the latest month for which figures are available: -

These were persons who claimed when registering that they were not employed and who were recorded as unplaced at the reporting date. The figures include those who, since registering, may have obtained employment without notifying the Commonwealth Employment Service, and persons who had been referred to employers with a view to engagement but whose placement was not confirmed at the reporting date; they also include persons receiving unemployment benefit.

item.para: Detailed statistics are not maintained of the age composition of the persons registered for employment at the Newtown district employment office, except as between adults and juniors under 21. Of the 702 males registered at 27th July, 1962, 654 were adults and 48 were under 21 years; and of the 438 females, 354 were adults and 84 were under 21.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice -

item.para: What has been the increase in teaching staff in each of the Australian universities in each of the last five years for which figures are available?
What was the staff/student ratio for each of those universities in each of those years?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honorable member's questions is as follows: -

item.label: 1 and 2.
item.para: The figures requested are given in the two tables below. In addition I mention that the total of staff referred to in table 1 was 3,479 in 1955 and 5,093 in 1960. The figures for 1961 have not been shown because the information now being prepared is not comparable with that for earlier years. As from 1961 revised returns have been used by the Commonwealth Statistician. These returns no longer show the actual numbers of part-time staff but, instead, provide the number of hours per annum worked by this staff.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice -

quote.para: Will he furnish a statement, using the latest figures available, showing the principal holders of Commonwealth Government securities (a) in Australia and (b) overseas?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honorable member's question is as follows: -

quote.para: Details of principal holders of Commonwealth securities in Australia at 30th June, 1961, the latest date for which information is available, are as follows: -

answer.para: No comparable information is available relating to holders of Commonwealth securities issued overseas.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Army, upon notice -

quote.para: If it takes three months for the Australian Army to mobilize and despatch 30 experts in jungle training to South Viet Nam, how long would it take Australia to send one division, if we had one division fully operational, to East New Guinea, if it was required in that region?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honorable member's question is as follows: -

quote.para: The timing of the despatch of the team of Australian instructors to South Viet Nam was determined in consultation with the Government of the Republic of Viet Nam. The honorable member will be aware that it is not the practice to disclose details of military capabilities or plans.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice -

item.para: Has he concluded his consideration of the recommendations of the Commonwealth Committee on Taxation, the report of which was presented to Parliament on 17th August, 1961?
If not, when does he expect to do so?
When does he expect to introduce legislation to give effect to all or any of the committee's recommendations?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honorable member's questions is: -

quote.para: An examination of the recommendations of the Commonwealth Committee on Taxation has revealed that many complex issues have been raised and that a task of some magnitude is involved. The recommendations will be kept under review but it is not practicable to indicate, at this stage, when any amending legislation may be introduced.

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice -

item.para: Is it a fact that, for the age allowance for taxation purposes, a husband over the age of 65 years is unduly disadvantaged where his wife is under age 60 as compared with a husband whose wife is over age 60?
Did the Committee on Taxation recommend that, provided the husband had attained an age of 65 years, the age of a wife should not be a condition in the application of the married couple age allowance?
If so, will he take steps to implement the recommendation of the committee.

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows: -

item.label: 1 and 3.
item.para: So far as age qualifications are concerned, the income tax age allowance is in consonance with the requirements of the Commonwealth age pension. Any departure from this basis would involve a question of policy requiring consideration and determination by the Government when income tax concessions are next under review.
Yes.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for External

item.para: What request did the Secretary of State of the United States of America make of the Australian Government with respect to - (a) the number and type of personnel for service, and (b) the quantity and type of material for use in Viet Nam?
What assistance has the Australian Government agreed to provide in each of these respects?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are -

item.para: The Secretary of State of the United States of America did not make any requests of the Australian Government during the Anzus meeting with regard to assistance for Viet Nam.

(a) The Australian Government has made available 30 highly skilled officer and noncommissioned officer instructors of the Regular Army to assist the Republic of Viet Nam in training its people in jungle warfare and village defence, (b) Apart from our Colombo Plan contribution (details of which were given in "Hansard" on 17th May, 1962), Australia has already spent or committed £200,000 under the Programme of Economic Aid for Seato Defence on the supply to Viet Nam of such items as telecommunications equipment, generators, firefighting equipment and barbed wire. Under the new £3,000,000 programme of assistance to the Asian members of Seato and the Republic of Viet Nam which was announced on 7th May, no hard and fast allocations are being made to individual recipient countries. Emphasis is, however, being placed on giving aid quickly to Viet Nam. This aid is destined chiefly for use in civil defence and consists of materials such as alarm sirens, flares, tents, barbed wire and steel posts for the protection of villages, and telephone and radio equipment.

What quantities of these commodities were produced in Australian oil refineries during these periods?
What amounts of (a) customs duty and (b) excise duty were received in respect of these commodities during these periods?
